III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 5/16/23, youth flicked staff member in the foot with a pencil
and then hid behind a desk. Staff member moved the desk and
grabbed youth by the sweatshirt and pushed youth out the door.
Youth is also made to sit on the floor for long lengths of time for
bad behaviors.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/17/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported Staff 1 tore his muscle in his leg and is in a leg brace. Staff
1 had his leg propped up while sitting in the school lobby with Youth
A. Youth A reported he tapped Staff 1 on the foot with a pencil and
then ran into the secretary area behind a desk to get away from
Staff 1. Youth A reported Staff 1 grabbed him by the sweatshirt and
pushed him outside the school building. Youth A described Staff 1
grabbing his sweatshirt by Staff 1 grabbing the back of Youth A’s
sweatshirt with both hands near his rib cage area and then shoved
Youth A outside the door. Youth A reported he did not remember if
there were any other youth or staff around that witnessed the
incident. Youth A reported he thought Staff 2 was in the secretary
office. Youth A reported “time out” is when a youth gets in trouble
for a behavior and must sit on the floor or the white chairs in the
house. “Time out” can range from fifteen minutes to fifteen hours.
Youth can only serve five hours of “time out” on school days as
there is school. Supervisors are the only ones approved to give
“time outs” to level one youth, staff can give “time outs” to all other
levels. Youth A reported he did “time out” on Monday. While in
“time out” youth can read, draw, watch tv, however are not able to
choose what to watch on tv or play video games. Youth A reported
while in “time out” youth are able to use the bathroom when needed
and eat meals with their peers.
2

Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/17/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B
reported he was in the school lobby area and witnessed the
incident. Youth B reported Youth A was “out of control” and Staff 1
escorted Youth A out of the school building. Youth B did not
remember where Staff 1’s hands were located on Youth A during
the escort. Youth A was saying he was going to kick Staff 1 in the
leg. Youth B reported he did not have any concerns with what he
saw. Youth B did not see Staff 1 push or shove Youth A at any time
during the incident.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/17/2023
in collaboration with MDHHS worker and via telephone on
6/16/2023. Staff 1 reported Youth A was antagonizing peers and
threated to hit Staff 1 in the knee. Staff 1 reported he currently has
a torn meniscus from a restraint and was viewed to be in a leg
brace. Youth A began hitting Staff 1’s knee with a pencil and then
ran out of the room into the secretary’s office area. Staff 1 followed
Youth A and was able to grab ahold of Youth A’s sweatshirt and
escort Youth A out of the school building. Staff 1 did not recall how
he grabbed Youth A’s sweatshirt, however stated it was for a
second. Staff 1 reported he grabbed Youth A’s sweatshirt in order
to get a hold of Youth A to get him in the escort hold to escort Youth
A out of the school as he was running around being “obnoxious.”
Staff 1 reported SCM teaches staff to use articles of clothing to pin
to the ground when in a supine restraint and he grabbed the
sweatshirt with the same idea in mind rather than grabbing Youth
A’s arm. Staff 1 described the escort as the trained escort hold per
Safe Crisis Management (SCM) technique. Staff 1 had his hands
positioned per the trained technique on Youth A’s back. Youth A
walked on his own will in the escort. Staff 1 called the office to have
Youth A removed from school. Staff 1 reported he did not shove or
push Youth A at any time during the incident. Staff 1 reported Youth
B was present and witnessed the incident. Staff 1 did not recall if
Staff 2 was present in the secretary area during the incident. Staff
1 reported when youth have behaviors resulting in loss of privileges,
youth are not allowed to talk to their peers, they can read, write,
draw, but do not get the extra privileges such as video games or
choosing what to watch on tv. Staff 1 reported loss of privileges is
used appropriately at the facility. Staff are able to restrict youth’s
privileges up to two and a half hours however anything over that
time needs to be approved by a supervisor.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/17/2023
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 reported she was
3

not in the secretary office when the incident occurred and did not
see the incident.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/17/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Administrator
reported youth loose privileges for behaviors at the facility and this
is viewed as a “time out.” Youth can lose privileges for five minutes
to three hours and if behaviors continue while in time out, this can
extend up to fifteen hours depending on the severity of the behavior.
Behaviors that result in loss of privileges include cussing, stealing,
property damage, youth AWOL, and assaultive behaviors. When a
youth loses privileges, they remain with the group however they are
not able to select tv shows to watch however can sit on the floor or
in a folding chair in the living room and watch tv but just not choose
what is being watched. The youth are not able to play video games
however can watch their peers play. Youth can read, write letters,
draw, and only talk to staff, not their peers. Administrator reported
Youth A has a difficult time respecting boundaries and has been
assaultive while at the facility. Administrator does not have any
concerns with Staff 1. Administrator does not have any concerns
with staff over using loss of privileges with youth. Staff are able to
make recommendations on lose of privileges however the
supervisor is the one who signs off on the consequences timeframe.
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 5/18/2023 and
reported they had no further information.
MDHHS worker does not have any findings in this
investigation.
Video Reviewed:
There was not camera footage able to be viewed due to no cameras
in the location.
Documents Reviewed:
• Pineview Homes Behavioral Support and Management
Policy: “Occasionally a non-compliant resident may need to be
escorted from one location to another, however the youth must
be allowed to walk on his own with no physical assistance from
staff members.”
• Safe Crisis Management Training Manual: Extended Arm Assist/
Escort: “If standing to the right side of the individual, place your
left hand (lead arm) on the individual’s shoulder blade (thumb in
armpit area) or grasping the individual’s shirt.”
• Pineview Homes Resident Handbook provides level system
for privileges and loss of privileges for behaviors.
4

• Staff 1’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record
and Staff 1 completed the required Safe Crisis
Management training on 2/21/2023 and 2/22/2023.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as Staff 1 and Youth B report
Youth A was not pushed or shoved during the incident.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
